title: Optics - Conditions for total internal reflection

content.question: If <math alttext="theta sub i" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>θ</mi> <mi>i</mi> </msub> </math> is varied, is it possible for the beam to be totally internally reflected? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because a portion of the beam is always reflected back whenever it encounters a new medium
Yes, because there will be an incident angle for which the refracted angle is <math alttext="90 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>
No, because a transparent medium must allow light to travel through it
No, because the beam will always refract toward the normal when going into a medium of greater index of refraction

content.answer: No, because the beam will always refract toward the normal when going into a medium of greater index of refraction
